awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Quantifying the contribution of alpine glacier meltwater to mountain-block recharge using microbiological markers and environmental isotopes
awd_abstract_narration:
Glaciers occur in mountains across the globe. Water from melting glaciers is important to humans and other organisms. Some of this water goes directly to streams while some will flow deep into the ground and refill groundwater. It is not known how much melt-water goes directly to streams versus to groundwater. This project uses water chemistry and biological data to determine where the water goes when a glacier melts. The project examines water from glaciers on Mt. Hood in Oregon and from glaciers in Glacier National Park in Montana. This project is training graduate students and multiple undergraduate students. The results are presented at scientific meetings and to water managers. The results are also available to the public via pamphlets and news articles.   

More than ninety percent of the Earth's alpine glaciers are in retreat and many of these glaciers will melt completely within this century. Very little research has been conducted on the impacts of alpine glacial meltwater to recharge and flow within the mountain block. This project seeks to identify the contribution of alpine glacial meltwater to mountain recharge relative to seasonal snow and rain using chemical and biological approaches. This research tests the following hypotheses: 1) The glacial environment selects for unique biota resulting in deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) fingerprints in alpine glacial meltwater that are distinct from seasonal snow and rain;  2) Alpine glacial meltwater is a significant source of mountain recharge and sustains perennial flow to local and regional-scale springs located down-gradient of alpine glaciers. This research assesses the novel application of DNA as a tracer for mountain recharge and increases the ability to detect recharge from alpine glaciers located in different geologic and geographic settings.  This study trains graduate students and multiple undergraduate researchers and engages with water managers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Mountain-block recharge (MBR) occurs when meltwater from snow (or possibly glacial ice) enters the water table in the high elevations of a mountainous watershed. We proposed that glacial meltwater could infiltrate and recharge both shallow aquifers occurring within glacial moraines and sediments as well as deep mountain-block aquifers hosted within bedrock and that the water balance of a glaciated alpine catchment would include recharge to both shallow and deep aquifers. However, there are considerable uncertainties regarding the partitioning of meltwater released from alpine glaciers, especially how much, if any of this glacial ice meltwater contributes to MBR. We tested the hypothesis that meltwater from alpine glaciers is a critical source of recharge for mountain groundwater systems using stable isotopic source-identification techniques. We collected over 100 samples from Mount Hood National Forest (MH) of Oregon, USA and Glacier National Park (GNP) of Montana, USA from 2016 to 2019. Glaciers are rapidly retreating in both MH and GNP but the sites varied in bedrock lithology as well as seasonal snow and precipitation, thus allowing us to examine the role of bedrock and seasonal precipitation on MBR. 

By comparing the isotopic composition of springs and streams to local snow, ice, and rain, we quantified the amount of glacial meltwater across our samples. We found that alpine glacier meltwater provides more than 90% of total flow to some springs and recharge from glacial meltwater is vital for maintaining flow in alpine springs. We conclude that glacial meltwater may be essential to the integrity of alpine aquatic ecosystems by maintaining baseflow in streams and perennial flow in springs. Quantification of MBR, particularly the fraction from glacial meltwater, could facilitate water conservation strategies and inform estimates of seasonal water supply as glaciers recede. 

We further hypothesized that glacial meltwater would host unique microbial communities that would serve as a tracer downstream. We sequenced 16S and 18S small subunit rRNA genes from our MH and GNP stream samples. We used a machine learning approach to examine the environmental parameters that best predict microbial community composition. While our data indicate glacial meltwater hosts unique microbial communities, specific bedrock characteristics were more important the meltwater source in predicting community composition. Bedrock resources including major anions and cations, silica, trace elements, and dissolved oxygen were better predictors of Mount Hood microbiomes while calcium and bicarbonate were important predictors of microbiomes in Glacier National Park springs and streams. Specific conductivity, temperature, and total dissolved solids were important predictors of community composition in streams at Mount Hood and Glacier National Park. Thus, ee found that alpine spring and stream environments differed between and within Mount Hood and Glacier National Park and that bedrock characteristics were more important predictors of microbial community composition than the meltwater source. 

Our data are summarized in The Glacier-Groundwater Connection: https://glacierrecharge.webflow.io.
